column7: Summary
column19: Internet of Things / BIM for Operations
column34: Capturing Waste Material from Other Industries

column7: Madaster is a register for materials and products used in a built construction. This platform generates a secure web-based passport of a registered building which contains the quality, origin and location of the materials used within the project and provides insight into the value of its reuse.

Houseful is a European based initiative which seeks to develop methodologies to quantify the circularity of projects, asses their potential environmental and socioeconomic impact, and deliver policy recommendations to local, regional and national levels. A series of projects across Europe will be used to demo HOUSEFUL's solutions.
Knowledge Hub provides searchable and curated links to circular case studies and resources across all industries.
Buildings As Material Banks (BAMB) is a project focused on developing the tools and policy needed to  enable a systemic shift from current models of linear construction to a circular economy.

column3: Old into new: Recycled bricks form facade of Copenhagen housing project
column7: This case study examines the use of recycled bricks in the facade of a Copenhagen housing project. Designed by Lendager, a firm in Denmark delivering sustainable building project solutions, the Resource Rows project demonstrates a powerful proof-of-concept for sourcing local materials from demolition and delivering innovative design.

column3: Urban Mining and Circular construction - what, why and how it works
column7: This essay from Merlijn Blok explores the concept of urban mining and its role in restructuring the built environment construction economy to recapture the millions of tons of demolition waste sent to landfill each year.

The Kalundborg Symbiosis is a case study in industrial symbiosis, and it demonstrates the immense potential of a circular flow of materials and energy to reduce negative social and environmental impact, and generate financial value.
Learn more about ShawContract EcoWorx products reclamation program and closed-loop cycle.

Current ownership models for products in the built environment typically results in goods and commodities being discarded at the end of their useful life. This article discusses how the leasing model can be applied to the built environment to make the industry more circular.

column3: Philips transition from linear to Circular Economy
column7: Philips discusses the transition to a circular model based on paying for a level of performance, rather than paying for product ownership.
This case study highlights the Quay Quarter Tower in Sydney, Australia.

column3: A Waterfront Eatery in Demark is Designed for Disassembly
column7: This waterfront eatery in Denmark demonstrates how a project can use the end of its useful life as a foundational tenet of its design.
Circle house is a proof of conccept. The project is fully demountable and uses minimal sealants to maintain construction material integretity to allow its reuse.

column3: Modular Architecture: When Beauty and Efficiency Meet
column7: Modular design can and has been being applied to the design world across many industries. This article gives the base for understanding what modular design is and how to approach it.

column3: The Potential of Prefab: How Modular Construction Can Be Green
column7: Here you will learn all the benefits of prefabrication, material optimization, and modular design in construction. This is a great overview that looks at these strategies wholistically, going from environmental impacts and working conditions all the way down to the more common benefits like quality control.
Serraview helps entities make the most of their estate through space management, space utilization, space planning, relocation management, activity based working strategies, and scenario planning.

column3: Efficient Design and Building Practices Can Effectively Reduce Your Waste Stream and Boost Your Bottom Line
column7: How can we create less new material and make the most of our existing material stock? This article explains the mind shift and strategies needed to keep our existing material stock in motion.

column3: The first 3D-printed housing community in the US is being built in the California Desert
column7: This project is a case study that looks into the benefits of 3D printed housing in comparison to a traditionally framed home.

column3: MEETS: A Win-Win Path to Deep Energy Efficiency
column7: MEETS is a perfect example of the Circular Economy in that it uses economics in its solution to make renewable energy attractive to all of its stakeholders. Here you will learn about the incentive to use renewables, and give energy back to the grid.

column3: IoT and its uses in buildings
column7: This is a great intro to the "Internet of Things" (IoT), what it is, how our industry uses it, and how it can be implemented.

We can demolish a building of one use and build another for a different use, but the circular economy would champion creativity to something new of the old. Here Archdaily is showcasing a number of projects that have done just that to divert construction material from the landfill and make new of the old.

Venlo City Hall does a great job at "regenerating natural systems", which is the third pillar of circularity. It's ability to use existing natural resources makes it emulate the the natural patterns of the land it sits on. Learn more here on how it is achieving its regenerative nature.

column3: What is the difference between recycling and upcycling
column7: There is much confusion across industries on the difference between recycling and upcycling. You can learn the differences here. These are important ideas to be aware of as the Circular Economy is built primarily on the idea up upcycling vs recycling.

When it comes to salvaging material or urban mining it is helpful for us to know which buildings in our urban setting may be ripe for harvesting. This list gives the average lifespans of building types so you can start to analyze where your city could begin its urban mining endeavor.
Brummen hall uses key strategies to being a ciruclar building. It is built using existing structure, boasts demountable materials, and utilizes material passports.
Circular Facades is a resource for design and construction professionals seaking inspiration and guidance through interactive tools, examples, strategies, and knowledge sharing.
This is as indepth article outlining the importance of and strategies to incoproate waste managment in the construction process.

column6: Case Study City Hall Venlo page 2.psd (c2c-centre.com)
column7: This case study examines City Hall Venlo in the Netherlands, and ambitous cradle to cradle inspired project.
Headbox is a spacesharing resource allowing users to book available spaces in venues accross the United Kingdom.
Globechain is a marketplace resource for built-enviornment products and materials.

Arup is a world leader in engineering and design consulting services, and in this case study they have used their expertise in a collaboration with The Living to study the use of a fungi and agricultural waste based brick.

RE-USE primarily provides consulting services, but also provides deconstruction services, and materials (on a limited basis). They are pioneers in the practical application of the circular economy in the built environment and are educating clients, designers, and contractors in the incredible financial and environmental benefits of building material harvesting and reuse.
Learn more here on how mixed use buildings can not only create a more livable, efficient city but also prolong the life of buildings.
Wilmington Waterfront park is a case study for how to utilize brownfield sites to deter the use and preserve our existing greenfield sites.
